transcript.text: My dear compatriots,
Once again, war has stricken our continent's soil.
Last night, Russia chose to attack Ukraine,

even though the Ukrainians did not attack
Russia, nor were they threatening it directly.
I fully condemn this use of force,

and my first thoughts go to the
victims of this absurd, fratricidal conflict

and to the French nationals
who are still on Ukrainian soil.
We could have avoided this disaster.

For years, I have been saying that the West has played
a role in the escalation of violence in the East

and that it needs to understand
Russia's demands against NATO's expansion.

Unfortunately, we have not done anything
to prevent this escalation.

I say "we" because we are all
responsible for this situation:

Russia, of course – and this morning they
are primarily responsible for what happened –
but also the West,

with NATO's continuous expansion
in Eastern Europe

and the failure to implement
the Minsk agreements.

For years, I have been saying that,
in order to be listened to,

France must restore balance to its relations
with the United States and Russia.

Like others,
including the Ukrainians themselves,

I did not think Vladimir Putin
would cross the red line,
because a peaceful solution was possible.

Since February 14, I have proposed that France, staying
true to its tradition as a great balancing power,
urgently negotiates with Europe and Russia
for a treaty that aims at stopping NATO's expansion.
This treaty would have several consequences:

the end of the territorial disputes
in Eastern Europe;

the respect of the freedom and sovereignty
of all countries involved, especially Ukraine;

and the withdrawal of Russian troops
from Ukraine's border.
It is not too late.

Such a treaty should be negotiated
during a peace conference in Paris.
We need lasting peace.
But the urgency now is to stop the fighting.

I solemnly call on President Macron
to go to Moscow and Kiev
to offer France's mediation

and negotiate a ceasefire
that would be effective immediately,

as did Nicolas Sarkozy
during the 2008 Georgian crisis.

This is what I would do
if I were president right now.
France can achieve such results

only if it plays its full role
as a balancing power.
France is a nuclear power

and is part of the UN Security Council,
just like Russia and the United States.
Therefore, France can legitimately step in

and create the conditions for
a reasonable conversation to occur.

Europe, from the Atlantic to the Urals,
must not be a battlefield.
I said it in Mont-Saint-Michel:

France has a duty of power
precisely to preserve peace.
This tragic situation confirms

that it is essential to strengthen
our national defense significantly.

This is why I want to increase our military
budget to 70 billion euros by 2030.
France must regain the attributes of its power.

It should be able to speak loudly
with an independent voice.

France must not submit to the United States,
Russia or anyone else.

It must take back control of its destiny
to contribute to the return of peace.

Long live peace, long live the Republic,
and above all, long live France.
